_**Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom**_ is a 2018 American [science
fiction](/wiki/Science_fiction_film "Science fiction film") [adventure
film](/wiki/Adventure_film "Adventure film") and the sequel to _[Jurassic
World](/wiki/Jurassic_World "Jurassic World")_ (2015). Directed by [J. A.
Bayona](/wiki/J._A._Bayona "J. A. Bayona"), it is the fifth installment of the
[_Jurassic Park_ film series](/wiki/Jurassic_Park "Jurassic Park"), as well as
the second installment of a planned _Jurassic World_ trilogy. [Derek
Connolly](/wiki/Derek_Connolly "Derek Connolly") and _Jurassic World_ director
[Colin Trevorrow](/wiki/Colin_Trevorrow "Colin Trevorrow") both returned as
writers, with Trevorrow and the original _[Jurassic
Park](/wiki/Jurassic_Park_\(film\) "Jurassic Park \(film\)")_ director [Steven
Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg") as executive producers.

Set on the fictional [Central American](/wiki/Central_America "Central
America") island of [Isla Nublar](/wiki/Isla_Nublar "Isla Nublar"), off the
[Pacific](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean") coast of [Costa
Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica "Costa Rica"), it follows [Owen
Grady](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Owen_Grady "List of Jurassic
Park characters") and [Claire
Dearing](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Claire_Dearing "List of
Jurassic Park characters") as they rescue the remaining dinosaurs before a
[volcanic eruption](/wiki/Volcano "Volcano") destroys it. [Chris
Pratt](/wiki/Chris_Pratt "Chris Pratt"), [Bryce Dallas
Howard](/wiki/Bryce_Dallas_Howard "Bryce Dallas Howard"), [B. D.
Wong](/wiki/B._D._Wong "B. D. Wong"), and [Jeff Goldblum](/wiki/Jeff_Goldblum
"Jeff Goldblum") reprise their roles from previous films in the series, with
[Rafe Spall](/wiki/Rafe_Spall "Rafe Spall"), [Justice
Smith](/wiki/Justice_Smith "Justice Smith"), [Daniella
Pineda](/wiki/Daniella_Pineda "Daniella Pineda"), [James
Cromwell](/wiki/James_Cromwell "James Cromwell"), [Toby
Jones](/wiki/Toby_Jones "Toby Jones"), [Ted Levine](/wiki/Ted_Levine "Ted
Levine"), Isabella Sermon, and [Geraldine Chaplin](/wiki/Geraldine_Chaplin
"Geraldine Chaplin") joining the cast.

Filming took place from February to July 2017 in the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") and [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii
"Hawaii"). Produced and distributed by [Universal
Pictures](/wiki/Universal_Pictures "Universal Pictures"), _Fallen Kingdom_
premiered in [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid") on May 21, 2018, and was released
internationally in early June 2018 and in the United States on June 22, 2018.
The film has grossed over $1.2 billion worldwide, making it the third
_Jurassic_ film to pass the billion dollar mark. It is the [third highest-
grossing film of 2018](/wiki/2018_in_film#Highest-grossing_films "2018 in
film") and the [12th highest-grossing film of all time](/wiki/List_of_highest-
grossing_films "List of highest-grossing films"). It received mixed reviews
from critics, who praised Pratt's performance, Bayona's direction, the
visuals, and the "surprisingly dark moments", while others suggested the
series had run its course, criticizing the screenplay and lack of
innovation.[8] An untitled sequel is set to be released on June 11, 2021, with
Trevorrow returning to direct.

## Plot

Shortly after the events of _[Jurassic World](/wiki/Jurassic_World "Jurassic
World")_ ,[9][10] a small team of [mercenaries](/wiki/Mercenary "Mercenary")
arrives on the abandoned [Isla Nublar](/wiki/Isla_Nublar "Isla Nublar") to
collect [DNA](/wiki/DNA "DNA") from the remains of the _[Indominus
rex](/wiki/List_of_cloned_animals_in_the_Jurassic_Park_series#Indominus_rex
"List of cloned animals in the Jurassic Park series")_ at the bottom of the
park's [lagoon](/wiki/Lagoon "Lagoon"). After successfully collecting a bone
fragment, the team's survivors barely escape the island following attacks by
the _[Mosasaurus](/wiki/Mosasaurus "Mosasaurus")_ and _[Tyrannosaurus
rex](/wiki/Tyrannosaurus "Tyrannosaurus")_.

Three years later in 2018, a [U.S. Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United
States Senate") hearing in [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C.
"Washington, D.C.") debates whether Isla Nublar's dinosaurs should be saved
from an impending volcanic eruption. Mathematician [Dr. Ian
Malcolm](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Dr._Ian_Malcolm "List of
Jurassic Park characters") testifies that the dinosaurs should be allowed to
perish to correct [John
Hammond's](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#John_Hammond "List of
Jurassic Park characters") mistake of [cloning](/wiki/Cloning "Cloning") them.
Meanwhile, Jurassic World's former operations manager Claire Dearing has
established the Dinosaur Protection Group to save the animals. After the
Senate rules against rescuing the dinosaurs, Hammond's former partner,
[Benjamin
Lockwood](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Sir_Benjamin_Lockwood "List
of Jurassic Park characters"), summons Claire Dearing to his [Northern
California](/wiki/Northern_California "Northern California") estate. Lockwood
and his aide, [Eli Mills](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Eli_Mills
"List of Jurassic Park characters"), reveal a plan to relocate the dinosaurs
to a new island sanctuary. Claire is needed to help reactivate the park's
dinosaur [tracking system](/wiki/GPS_wildlife_tracking "GPS wildlife
tracking") to locate the animals, particularly Blue, the last living
_[Velociraptor](/wiki/Velociraptor "Velociraptor")_. Although they are
estranged, Claire recruits Jurassic World's former _Velociraptor_ trainer and
Blue's alpha, Owen Grady, to help capture her.

On Isla Nublar, Claire and former park technician [Franklin
Webb](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Franklin_Webb "List of Jurassic
Park characters") get the [tracking system](/wiki/GPS_wildlife_tracking "GPS
wildlife tracking") online. Owen, paleo-veterinarian [Zia
Rodriguez](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Dr._Zia_Rodriguez "List of
Jurassic Park characters"), and a mercenary team led by [Ken
Wheatley](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Ken_Wheatley "List of
Jurassic Park characters") search for Blue. On finding her, the encounter
escalates, resulting in a mercenary shooting Blue and Wheatley
[tranquilizing](/wiki/Sedative "Sedative") Owen. The mercenaries take Zia so
she can treat Blue's injury. Their ship departs for the [U.S.
mainland](/wiki/Contiguous_United_States "Contiguous United States") as the
animals left behind die in the eruption. Claire, Franklin, and Owen sneak
aboard in time and assist Zia in [transfusing](/wiki/Blood_transfusion "Blood
transfusion") Blue with _Tyrannosaurus_ blood. The group now realize the
captured dinosaurs were never being transported to a new island and are for
another purpose.

Back at the estate, Lockwood's orphaned pre-teen granddaughter
[Maisie](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Maisie_Lockwood "List of
Jurassic Park characters") overhears Mills and auctioneer [Gunnar
Eversol](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Gunnar_Eversol "List of
Jurassic Park characters") secretly planning to auction the captured dinosaurs
on the [black market](/wiki/Black_market "Black market"). They will also
unveil the
_[Indoraptor](/wiki/List_of_cloned_animals_in_the_Jurassic_Park_series#Indoraptor
"List of cloned animals in the Jurassic Park series")_ , a new [genetically-
engineered](/wiki/Genetic_engineering "Genetic engineering") dinosaur created
by geneticist [Dr. Henry
Wu](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Dr._Henry_Wu "List of Jurassic Park
characters") using _Indominus rex_ and _Velociraptor_ DNA. Wu wants Blue's DNA
to create an enhanced _Indoraptor_ , unaware that Blue's blood is
contaminated. After Maisie informs Lockwood about the auction, he confronts
Mills, who murders him. Maisie is later revealed to have been cloned from
Lockwood's deceased daughter and is the reason John Hammond, who opposed
[human cloning](/wiki/Human_cloning "Human cloning"), ended their partnership.

The dinosaurs are transported to Lockwood's estate and caged. Zia and Franklin
evade capture, but Owen and Claire are apprehended and confined. Owen incites
a _[Stygimoloch](/wiki/Stygimoloch "Stygimoloch")_ into breaking open their
cell. They find Maisie who leads them to the auction where the _Indoraptor_ is
being sold despite Wu's protests that it is a prototype. Owen disrupts the
proceedings by luring the _Stygimoloch_ into the room. In the ensuing chaos,
Wheatley tranquilizes the _Indoraptor_ to extract a tooth as a trophy, but it
feigns sedation and escapes, killing him, Eversol, and others. The
_Indoraptor_ hunts Owen, Claire, and Maisie throughout the mansion. Zia
releases Blue, who attacks the _Indoraptor_ , causing it to fall through a
glass roof to its death.

When a [hydrogen cyanide](/wiki/Hydrogen_cyanide "Hydrogen cyanide") gas leak
threatens the caged animals, Maisie is unable to let them die and frees them
despite Owen's warning. Mills is killed and the _Indominus_ bone is destroyed
by the _Tyrannosaurus_. Owen, Claire, Maisie, Zia, and Franklin get away
safely, while Blue and the other dinosaurs escape.

In a new U.S. Senate hearing, Dr. Malcolm declares the beginning of a Neo-
Jurassic Age where humans and dinosaurs must learn to coexist. The closing
scenes show the freed dinosaurs roaming wilderness and outer urban areas.

## Cast

Main article: [List of Jurassic Park
characters](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters "List of Jurassic Park
characters")

  * [Chris Pratt](/wiki/Chris_Pratt "Chris Pratt") as Owen Grady: A [Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy") veteran and former _Velociraptor_ handler for Jurassic World.[11]
  * [Bryce Dallas Howard](/wiki/Bryce_Dallas_Howard "Bryce Dallas Howard") as Claire Dearing: Jurassic World's former [operations manager](/wiki/Operations_management "Operations management"), now a dinosaur-rights [activist](/wiki/Activism "Activism"), who has founded the Dinosaur Protection Group in [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") to save Isla Nublar's surviving dinosaurs.[11][12]
  * [Rafe Spall](/wiki/Rafe_Spall "Rafe Spall") as Eli Mills:   
Lockwood's ambitious assistant who recruits Owen and Claire to rescue the
dinosaurs. Speaking of his character’s actions over the course of the film,
Spall noted that, "Ambition is such a powerful emotion, you can get wrapped up
in it and end up doing things in order to succeed. This character believes he
is doing right. He has been entrusted with pushing Lockwood’s fortune into the
future and making it survive after he dies. Mills feels he is simply doing
what he was asked to do."[13][3]

  * [Justice Smith](/wiki/Justice_Smith "Justice Smith") as Franklin Webb: A former [IT technician](/wiki/Information_systems_technician "Information systems technician") for Jurassic World who is now the Dinosaur Protection Group's [systems analyst](/wiki/Systems_analyst "Systems analyst") and [hacker](/wiki/Hacking_\(computer_security\) "Hacking \(computer security\)").[14][12]
  * [Daniella Pineda](/wiki/Daniella_Pineda "Daniella Pineda") as Zia Rodriguez: A former [Marine](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps") who is now the Dinosaur Protection Group's paleoveterinarian.[14][12][3]
  * [James Cromwell](/wiki/James_Cromwell "James Cromwell") as Sir Benjamin Lockwood: [John Hammond](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#John_Hammond "List of Jurassic Park characters")'s former partner in developing the technology to clone dinosaurs.[15][16]
  * [Toby Jones](/wiki/Toby_Jones "Toby Jones") as Gunnar Eversol:   
An auctioneer host at Lockwood Estate who sells the Isla Nublar dinosaurs for
profit.[17][3] In an interview, Jones likened his character to that of "a
rogue arms dealer; he sees profits in selling these creatures as weapons. He
is totally morally neutral about whatever he is selling. He is only interested
in whether or not it will make him a profit."[3]

  * [Ted Levine](/wiki/Ted_Levine "Ted Levine") as Ken Wheatley: A seasoned mercenary who commands the rescue operation on Isla Nublar.[3]
  * [B. D. Wong](/wiki/B._D._Wong "B. D. Wong") as Henry Wu:   
The former head [geneticist](/wiki/Geneticist "Geneticist") of both Jurassic
World and the original Jurassic Park. Speaking of his character’s actions,
Wong stated: "I do think he’s motivated by his love for science and his own
ego, which is well supported by his massive achievements ... I think he turns
a blind eye to the human suffering that comes as a result because he thinks
he’s looking at some bigger picture."[18][19]

  * Isabella Sermon as Maisie Lockwood: Lockwood's juvenile granddaughter and legal ward following her parents' deaths.[20][21][22][23]
  * [Geraldine Chaplin](/wiki/Geraldine_Chaplin "Geraldine Chaplin") as Iris: The Lockwood Estate housekeeper, Maisie's nanny, and protector of the Lockwood family secrets.[24][3]
  * [Jeff Goldblum](/wiki/Jeff_Goldblum "Jeff Goldblum") as [Ian Malcolm](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Dr._Ian_Malcolm "List of Jurassic Park characters"):   
An expert in [chaos theory](/wiki/Chaos_theory "Chaos theory") who once
consulted for [InGen](/wiki/InGen "InGen")'s Jurassic Park.[25] In a podcast
interview, Goldblum spoke of his role "It's small… who knows, they may cut me
out entirely! But if I stay in, I'll be a sprig of parsley or a little
garnish, hopefully with some impact!"[26][27] Director Bayona confirmed that
Goldblum's role is simply a [cameo](/wiki/Cameo_appearance "Cameo
appearance"), stating, "He doesn't have a major role in the action but it's
definitely a very meaningful one in terms of the story."[28]

  * [Peter Jason](/wiki/Peter_Jason "Peter Jason") as Senator Sherwood: A Senator who is among those who debate about saving the dinosaurs on Isla Nublar.

## Production

### Development

During early conversations about the 2015 film _[Jurassic
World](/wiki/Jurassic_World "Jurassic World")_ , executive producer [Steven
Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg") told director [Colin
Trevorrow](/wiki/Colin_Trevorrow "Colin Trevorrow") that he was interested in
having several more films made.[29] In April 2014, Trevorrow announced that
sequels had been discussed: "We wanted to create something that would be a
little bit less arbitrary and episodic, and something that could potentially
arc into a series that would feel like a complete story."[30] Trevorrow said
[Chris Pratt](/wiki/Chris_Pratt "Chris Pratt") and [Omar Sy](/wiki/Omar_Sy
"Omar Sy") might reprise their roles for the next few films and that he would
direct the film if asked.[30] He later told Spielberg he would only focus on
directing one film in the series,[29] but in May 2015, Trevorrow announced
that he would not direct another film: "I would be involved in some way, but
not as director." He felt different directors could bring different qualities
to future films.[31] Pratt had been signed for future films in the series,[32]
as was [Ty Simpkins](/wiki/Ty_Simpkins "Ty Simpkins"), who portrayed Gray in
_Jurassic World_.[33]

On June 3, 2015, Trevorrow said that _Jurassic World_ left many story
possibilities open: "I really like the idea that this group of geneticists
aren't the only people who can make a dinosaur […] when you think of the
differences between [Apple](/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.") and
[PC](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer")—the minute something goes
[open-source](/wiki/Open_source "Open source"), there are all kinds of
entities and interests that may be able to utilize that technology."[34] On
June 8, 2015, _Jurassic World_ producer [Frank
Marshall](/wiki/Frank_Marshall_\(producer\) "Frank Marshall \(producer\)") met
with Trevorrow and [Universal Pictures](/wiki/Universal_Pictures "Universal
Pictures") to discuss a sequel.[35] Later that month, he did not deny the film
could involve "dinosaur soldiers"[36] and said the series is "not always gonna
be about a Jurassic Park". He felt future films could explore the idea of
dinosaurs and humans co-existing.[29] Trevorrow also hinted the next film
might not involve the Jurassic World theme park,[37] and said he would be
interested in seeing a _Jurassic Park_ film made by one of several unnamed
Spanish horror film directors.[38]

### Pre-production

On July 23, 2015, Universal announced a fifth film had been scheduled for a
June 22, 2018, release date in the U.S. It was also announced that Trevorrow
would write the script with his writing partner [Derek
Connolly](/wiki/Derek_Connolly "Derek Connolly"), as they had for _Jurassic
World_ ; that the film would be produced by Frank Marshall; and that Spielberg
and Trevorrow would act as executive producers. Universal also said that Chris
Pratt and [Bryce Dallas Howard](/wiki/Bryce_Dallas_Howard "Bryce Dallas
Howard") would reprise their roles from the previous film.[11] At the time of
the film's announcement, Trevorrow said the series "isn't always going to be
limited to theme parks". He confirmed the film would not involve "a bunch of
dinosaurs chasing people on an island" stating, "That'll get old real
fast."[39] Trevorrow also spoke of the film's possible open-source storyline:
"It's almost like [InGen](/wiki/InGen "InGen") is [Mac](/wiki/Mac_OS "Mac
OS"), but what if PC gets their hands on it? What if there are 15 different
entities around the world who can make a dinosaur?"[39]

In August 2015, Howard said the script was being written,[40] and it was
announced the film would be released in the UK two weeks early, on June 7,
2018.[41] Later that year, [B. D. Wong](/wiki/B._D._Wong "B. D. Wong") said he
"would be happy to return" as [Dr. Henry
Wu](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Dr._Henry_Wu "List of Jurassic Park
characters"),[42] while Howard announced that filming would begin in 2017.[43]
Howard also said she would be interested in seeing characters from earlier
_Jurassic Park_ films return for the fifth film, saying, "I could see versions
of the film where a lot of the characters come back."[44] By October 2015,
director [J. A. Bayona](/wiki/J._A._Bayona "J. A. Bayona") was being
considered to direct the film. He chose instead to direct the [_World War Z_
sequel](/wiki/World_War_Z_\(film\)#Sequel "World War Z \(film\)"), a project
for which he had already signed on.[45] In January 2016, it was reported that
Bayona could still be a candidate to direct the film after he dropped out of
the _World War Z_ sequel due to other commitments.[46]

In March 2016, [London](/wiki/London "London") was being
[scouted](/wiki/Location_scouting "Location scouting") as a possible filming
location and setting for the film;[47] it was subsequently announced that
filming would take place at a UK studio.[48] On April 14, 2016, actor [Jeff
Goldblum](/wiki/Jeff_Goldblum "Jeff Goldblum") said he had no plans to appear
in the film as his character [Ian
Malcolm](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Dr._Ian_Malcolm "List of
Jurassic Park characters"), although he said he was open to the
possibility.[49] On April 18, 2016, Bayona was announced as the film's
director, with Belén Atienza and Patrick Crowley joining Marshall as
producers.[50] Spielberg, Marshall, and [Kathleen
Kennedy](/wiki/Kathleen_Kennedy_\(producer\) "Kathleen Kennedy \(producer\)")
had been impressed by his 2012 film, _[The
Impossible](/wiki/The_Impossible_\(2012_film\) "The Impossible \(2012
film\)")_ , and initially considered having him direct _Jurassic World_. He
declined as he felt there was not enough time for production.[51][52]
Trevorrow wanted Bayona to direct the film after seeing his 2007 horror film,
_[The Orphanage](/wiki/The_Orphanage_\(film\) "The Orphanage
\(film\)")_.[53][54] Before he was hired, Bayona had met with Trevorrow and
became enthused with the project after being shown the script's second half,
which would play out like a haunted house film.[55] After Bayona was hired,
Trevorrow said of the film, "We're moving it into new territory. J. A. Bayona
is an incredible director and I know he'll push the boundaries of what a
'Jurassic' movie is. I think it's important that we take risks. A franchise
must evolve or perish."[56] Trevorrow and Bayona worked closely throughout the
film's production.[3] In June 2016, actor [Sam Neill](/wiki/Sam_Neill "Sam
Neill") was asked if he would return to the series as Dr. Alan Grant and
responded, "You never say never, but I think it's moved on. It's different
times."[57]

The film, under the [working title](/wiki/Working_title "Working title") of
_Ancient Futures_ ,[58] was in full pre-production as of July 2016, with
[storyboards](/wiki/Storyboard "Storyboard") being designed.[59] [Andy
Nicholson](/wiki/Andy_Nicholson_\(production_designer\) "Andy Nicholson
\(production designer\)") was hired as the film's [production
designer](/wiki/Production_designer "Production designer"). He spent four
weeks with Bayona in [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), discussing
reference pictures and background details, as well as Bayona's ideas for the
Lockwood mansion.[3] Production was scheduled to begin in Hawaii in February
2017.[60][61] [Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales") was also confirmed as a filming
location,[62] including [Brecon Beacons](/wiki/Brecon_Beacons "Brecon
Beacons") and [Penbryn](/wiki/Penbryn "Penbryn").[63] Trevorrow said that
Hawaii would be used as a primary filming location, while U.K. shooting would
be limited to studios, without the story taking place there. Trevorrow also
said the film would feature many dinosaurs that were not seen in previous
films and denied that the film's story would involve militarized dinosaurs,
which would only be mentioned in the film.[64]

For the film's second half where dinosaurs are transported by boat to the
mainland, [Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador") and [Peru](/wiki/Peru "Peru") had
both been scouted as possible filming locations and settings. Marshall thought
that [Cabo San Lucas](/wiki/Cabo_San_Lucas "Cabo San Lucas") would be ideal,
but these locations ultimately did not work for the film's story. Although the
film was shot partly in England, Spielberg felt the country was too far from
the fictional Isla Nublar to be used as the in-film setting for the second
half. He and the producers did not want the film to spend too much time on a
boat. Crowley stated, "Rather than making it a movie about traveling on a
boat, which is not very exciting, you needed to get to the place."[65]

In September 2016, Bayona confirmed the film would be the second chapter in a
planned _Jurassic World_ trilogy.[66] Later that year, Marshall said that Wong
was "probably going to come back".[67] _Jurassic World_ composer [Michael
Giacchino](/wiki/Michael_Giacchino "Michael Giacchino") confirmed that he
would return as composer for the fifth film.[68] [Óscar
Faura](/wiki/%C3%93scar_Faura "Óscar Faura") was announced as the film's
cinematographer at the end of the year.[69]

### Writing

Although Spielberg was heavily involved in the development of ideas for
_Jurassic World_ , he had Trevorrow and Connolly devise their own ideas for
the sequel. He retained final approval on the project.[70] In June 2015, about
two weeks after the theatrical release of _Jurassic World_ , Trevorrow
embarked on a road trip from Los Angeles to his home state of Vermont.
Connolly agreed to accompany Trevorrow so they could discuss a basic set of
ideas Trevorrow had for the film.[3] During their eight-day trip,[71] they
began work on the script and devised the basic story.[72][73] Trevorrow said
the film's story was inspired by a quote from [Dr. Alan
Grant](/wiki/Dr._Alan_Grant "Dr. Alan Grant") in [the first
film](/wiki/Jurassic_Park_\(film\) "Jurassic Park \(film\)"): "Dinosaurs and
man, two species separated by 65 million years of evolution, have suddenly
been thrown back into the mix together. How can we possibly have the slightest
idea of what to expect?"[74] Trevorrow said that the story was heavily
influenced by the idea that, "A mistake made a long time ago just can't be
undone."[64]

The film is also based on concepts from [Michael
Crichton](/wiki/Michael_Crichton "Michael Crichton")'s novel _[Jurassic
Park](/wiki/Jurassic_Park_\(novel\) "Jurassic Park \(novel\)")_ (1990) and its
sequel _[The Lost World](/wiki/The_Lost_World_\(Crichton_novel\) "The Lost
World \(Crichton novel\)")_ (1995), and includes dialogue from the first
novel.[64] Isla Nublar's volcano was in the first novel, and the writers chose
to incorporate it into the film's plot.[75] Trevorrow compared the destruction
of Isla Nublar to "the burning down of a church or a temple," saying, "I
honestly think it's like killing off a character in a way, and if you're going
to do that, as long as you approach it with the proper respect and
acknowledgement that you understand how indelible and permanent what you're
doing is, then hopefully people will have an emotional response but they won't
hate you for it."[76] The idea to include a "silent partner" for John Hammond
was also inspired by the _Jurassic Park_ novel. Although the character of
Benjamin Lockwood was not featured in the novel, the book depicts the early
years leading up to the cloning of dinosaurs. This made Trevorrow realize
there would have been many people involved in such a project, convincing him
that someone like Lockwood would be among those people.[77]

In his initial [film treatment](/wiki/Film_treatment "Film treatment"),
Trevorrow had included story elements that Marshall and Crowley considered
excessive for a single film. The producers felt it was important to include
details about Owen and Claire's lives after the events of _Jurassic
World_.[65] Although the original ending was the same as the final film,
Trevorrow had wanted to include more details about the integration of
dinosaurs into the world. He chose to remove them to keep the story
focused.[78] The script's structure, Trevorrow said, was inspired by
Spielberg's 2015 film _[Bridge of Spies](/wiki/Bridge_of_Spies_\(film\)
"Bridge of Spies \(film\)")_ , in which two seemingly unrelated stories
"collide in the middle, and move on together."[70] Trevorrow was also inspired
by the 1975 film _[Three Days of the Condor](/wiki/Three_Days_of_the_Condor
"Three Days of the Condor")_ , saying, "It's one of those places where you
think you know what the score is, and then everything changes, and then
suddenly you don't know who to trust."[70] Having directed _Jurassic World_ ,
Trevorrow was familiar with how [animatronics](/wiki/Animatronics
"Animatronics") worked and wrote scenes for the sequel that would allow for
their use. For example, animatronics are incapable of certain actions such as
running.[79]

Regarding the idea of [human cloning](/wiki/Human_cloning "Human cloning"),
Trevorrow said that "we're so much closer to cloning humans than we are to
cloning dinosaurs. It felt like far less of a leap to me than dinosaurs do.
[...] To have a character who has such deep love and has felt such loss and
the inability to go on, I think is something we all feel. So the idea that you
might be able to bring someone back in that way is emotionally grounded in a
very universal idea."[80] Trevorrow also said he was interested in "the larger
impact" of genetic power, including its emotional impact and its potential
human impact. He added, "we knew that we didn't want to continue to make
movies about the dangers of messing with science. We want to tell a story
about where we are now, which is that we _have_ messed with science, we _have_
fundamentally altered our world and now we're dealing with the
consequences."[77] Trevorrow was nervous about how audiences would react to
the story's human cloning aspect, an idea supported by Spielberg, who was
excited about the questions that such an idea could raise in the film's
sequel.[76] Because of criticism of the death of
[Zara](/wiki/List_of_Jurassic_Park_characters#Zara_Young "List of Jurassic
Park characters") in the previous film, Trevorrow said for _Jurassic World:
Fallen Kingdom_ , "We made sure that every death was earned. Everybody
deserves their death in this movie, a lesson learned. In 2018 everyone earns
it. Horrible people."[76]

After Bayona was hired, he began reading Crichton's novels—including _Jurassic
Park_ and _The Lost World_ —for inspiration and "to try to immerse myself in
Crichton's mind."[81][82] Trevorrow and Connolly began working with Bayona in
July 2016, to perfect the script to the director's liking.[64] Trevorrow said
the film would be more "suspenseful and scary" than its predecessor: "It's
just the way it's designed; it's the way the story plays out. I knew I wanted
Bayona to direct it long before anyone ever heard that it was a possibility,
so the whole thing was just built around his skillset."[64] Trevorrow later
described the film as "_The Impossible_ meets _The Orphanage_ with
dinosaurs."[54] Bayona said that with the first half of the film set on an
island, "you have what you expect from a _Jurassic_ movie," while the second
half "moves to a totally different environment that feels more suspenseful,
darker, claustrophobic, and even has this kind of gothic element, which I
love."[83] The "gothic element" of suspense was influenced by [Alfred
Hitchcock](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock "Alfred Hitchcock") films.[84] He compared
it to _[The Empire Strikes Back](/wiki/The_Empire_Strikes_Back "The Empire
Strikes Back")_ and _[Star Trek II: The Wrath of
Khan](/wiki/Star_Trek_II:_The_Wrath_of_Khan "Star Trek II: The Wrath of
Khan")_ , which were both considered darker than their predecessors.[85]

Trevorrow said the film's dinosaurs would be "a parable of the treatment
animals receive today: the abuse, medical experimentation, pets, having wild
animals in zoos like prisons, the use the military has made of them, animals
as weapons."[86] The idea of weaponized dinosaurs came from Spielberg.[71][87]
Trevorrow said that with the film's dinosaur auction, "The worst instincts of
mankind are revealed. The first film was very clearly about corporate greed.
This is just about human greed."[88] The film includes ideas previously
featured in a rejected 2004 draft for _Jurassic Park IV_ (later _Jurassic
World_), presented in the same structure: a return to Isla Nublar followed by
a second half set in a large [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic
architecture") building on the mainland. The idea of a dinosaur auction was
also in the rejected draft, which Trevorrow had read while writing the first
_Jurassic World_ film.[89][90]

Bayona had his own ideas incorporated into the script while essentially
retaining the original story devised by Trevorrow and Connolly.[59] The film's
underwater opening sequence was already in their script. Bayona asked
Trevorrow to push for it to become a bigger scene with a larger set.[55] One
of Trevorrow's ideas was to include [Jeff Goldblum](/wiki/Jeff_Goldblum "Jeff
Goldblum")'s character of Ian Malcolm, who appeared in the franchise's earlier
films.[91] Trevorrow and Goldblum discussed dialogue ideas for Malcolm, and
Trevorrow said he used a lot of dialogue from Crichton's _Jurassic Park_ novel
for the character.[3][92] Marshall said that Trevorrow wrote Malcolm as "the
'Uh oh, danger, I told you so' kind of character".[52] Trevorrow said of
Malcolm, "I saw him as kind of [Al Gore](/wiki/Al_Gore "Al Gore"). He's got a
beard now, and he's like, 'I told all of you this was going to be a disaster,
and sure enough it is.'"[93] Bayona and Trevorrow ultimately removed certain
moments from the script they felt would be better for the sequel, which was
expected to depict dinosaurs having spread around the world.[76]

### Casting

In October 2016, casting was underway for the role of a nine-year-old
girl.[94] Approximately 2,500 girls were interviewed for the part, which
ultimately went to Isabella Sermon, marking her film debut.[3] By November
2016, [Tom Holland](/wiki/Tom_Holland_\(actor\) "Tom Holland \(actor\)")—who
previously starred in _The Impossible_ —had discussed a role in the film with
Bayona, but did not believe he would be available because of scheduling
conflicts.[95] [Toby Jones](/wiki/Toby_Jones "Toby Jones"), [Rafe
Spall](/wiki/Rafe_Spall "Rafe Spall"), and [Justice Smith](/wiki/Justice_Smith
"Justice Smith") were cast at the end of the year.[96][97][98]

[Daniella Pineda](/wiki/Daniella_Pineda "Daniella Pineda"), [Ted
Levine](/wiki/Ted_Levine "Ted Levine") and [James
Cromwell](/wiki/James_Cromwell "James Cromwell") were cast in early
2017,[99][100][16] while Wong confirmed his return as Dr. Henry Wu.[18] To
maintain secrecy, the _Ancient Futures_ title was used in the casting phase.
During auditions, references to dinosaurs were replaced with animals such as
lions and grizzly bears.[101][102] To convince the studio that Pineda was
right for the role of Zia, Bayona had her demonstrate she could perform comedy
and drama scenes, as well as [improvise](/wiki/Improvisation "Improvisation").
Pineda auditioned seven times before being given the role. She auditioned for
Bayona, Atienza, and Crowley but did not meet the cast until she arrived in
England for filming.[103]

In March 2017, Bayona announced that [Geraldine
Chaplin](/wiki/Geraldine_Chaplin "Geraldine Chaplin"), who had appeared in
each of his previous films, had joined the cast.[24] The next month, it was
announced that [Jeff Goldblum](/wiki/Jeff_Goldblum "Jeff Goldblum") would be
reprising his role from the first two films as Dr. Ian Malcolm.[25] Bayona
considered Malcolm a "great character!"[82] Marshall said, "The world has
changed a lot since Ian Malcolm went to Jurassic Park and we need his point of
view now more than ever. He told us about chaos theory, he was right."[104]

### Filming

Filming began at Langley Business Centre in [Slough](/wiki/Slough "Slough"),
England, on February 23, 2017.[105][106] Scenes shot at the business center
included Claire's Dinosaur Protection Group office, Owen training his baby
raptors, and Owen and Claire attempting to retrieve blood from the sedated _T.
rex_.[3] Most of the filming in England took place at [Pinewood
Studios](/wiki/Pinewood_Studios "Pinewood Studios").[107] Because of its large
[sound stages](/wiki/Sound_stage "Sound stage"), it was considered perfect for
the film's many interior scenes.[65] After filming concluded in England,
production moved to [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii"),[108] which was used as a
primary filming location.[64] Scenes shot in Hawaii were set on [Isla
Nublar](/wiki/Isla_Nublar "Isla Nublar"), the fictional island featured in the
first and fourth films.[109] Scenes were also expected to be shot at [Brecon
Beacons National Park](/wiki/Brecon_Beacons_National_Park "Brecon Beacons
National Park") in Wales.[110] The film was shot in
[CinemaScope](/wiki/CinemaScope "CinemaScope"), and is the first entry in the
_Jurassic Park_ series presented in a 2.40:1 [aspect
ratio](/wiki/Aspect_ratio_\(image\) "Aspect ratio \(image\)"). The film crew
used [Arri Alexa 65](/wiki/Arri_Alexa#Alexa_65 "Arri Alexa") exclusively.[91]
Several scenes were shot to reference various films including _[From Here to
Eternity](/wiki/From_Here_to_Eternity "From Here to Eternity")_ (1953) and
_[Dracula](/wiki/Dracula_\(1979_film\) "Dracula \(1979 film\)")_ (1979), as
well as Spielberg's films _[Raiders of the Lost
Ark](/wiki/Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark "Raiders of the Lost Ark")_ (1981) and
_[E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial](/wiki/E.T._the_Extra-Terrestrial "E.T. the
Extra-Terrestrial")_ (1982).[76][111] Spielberg was shown scenes from the film
during production and offered Bayona his opinions.[53]

During filming, and in between [takes](/wiki/Take "Take"), Bayona used an
[iPod](/wiki/IPod "IPod") to play different types of music on set to inspire
the actors, as he had done with his previous films.[112][113] He also played
sound effects from other films in the series,[114] including a _T. rex_ roar
that he sometimes used to get a natural reaction from the actors.[115] In
particular, Bayona played unexpected sounds and loud music to scare Smith for
certain scenes, as his character is portrayed as easily frightened.[101][112]
Bayona and Pratt discussed each scene involving Owen's character before it was
shot. Many of Pratt's ideas were used in the film. Discussing Levine's
character, Bayona said, "He came with this idea of creating this kind of
military man. He just wanted to portray the most hateable character possible.
[…] And he was so creative on set, trying to give ideas, bringing story notes
to make this character more and more hateable."[55] The film includes several
indirect references to U.S. President [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump
"Donald Trump"), including an idea from Trevorrow where a [news
ticker](/wiki/News_ticker "News ticker") says the "U.S. president" has
questioned the "existence of dinosaurs in the first place."[116][117][76][118]
Jones was allowed to decide his character's appearance, which included a wig
similar to [Trump's hairstyle](/wiki/Donald_Trump%27s_hair "Donald Trump's
hair").[76][117] An unscripted moment left in the film involves Levine's
character referring to Pineda's character Zia as a "[nasty
woman](/wiki/Nasty_woman "Nasty woman")", a comment that was previously made
famous by Trump.[117][119][118]

In April 2017, scenes were filmed at [East Berkshire
College](/wiki/East_Berkshire_College "East Berkshire College") in
[Berkshire](/wiki/Berkshire "Berkshire"), England,[120] and at [Loch
Long](/wiki/Loch_Long "Loch Long") in [Argyll and Bute](/wiki/Argyll_and_Bute
"Argyll and Bute"), Scotland.[121] Also that month, filming took place at
Hartland Park—formerly the [Pyestock jet engine test
site](/wiki/National_Gas_Turbine_Establishment "National Gas Turbine
Establishment")—in [Fleet, Hampshire](/wiki/Fleet,_Hampshire "Fleet,
Hampshire"), England,[122][123] where the film's opening sequence was shot. It
was filmed through the night and involved helicopters, rain machines, and
lightning simulators to depict a thunderstorm.[3] Bayona described the opening
scene as a "massive action piece" that resembled the
[prologues](/wiki/Prologue "Prologue") used in [James Bond
films](/wiki/List_of_James_Bond_films "List of James Bond films").[124] Scenes
were filmed on sets at [Hawley Common](/wiki/Hawley,_Hampshire "Hawley,
Hampshire"), also in Hampshire,[123] where the exterior of Lockwood's mansion
was built, as well as a mainland loading dock where the dinosaurs are
brought.[3] The exterior of the ship that transports Isla Nublar's dinosaurs
to the mainland was created entirely through computer-generated effects by
[Industrial Light & Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic "Industrial Light
& Magic") (ILM), which worked on the previous films. The ship's interior was
constructed by Nicholson and his team as a large set at Pinewood Studios, and
after filming, it was rebuilt to depict the large rooftop of the Lockwood
Estate.[3] The exterior of the [Cragside](/wiki/Cragside "Cragside") country
house in [Northumberland](/wiki/Northumberland "Northumberland"), England,
along with its [coniferous](/wiki/Conifer "Conifer") surroundings, was used to
depict the Lockwood Estate exterior. The film crew took [plate
shots](/wiki/Motion_control_photography "Motion control photography") of
Cragside and used a computer to combine the shots with footage filmed on set
to create the exterior of the Lockwood Estate. No actors were involved in the
Cragside shoot.[125][126]

Nicholson [previsualized](/wiki/Previsualization "Previsualization") each of
the sets he and his team built to ensure they would be large enough for the
intended scenes. He noted, "Someone can tell you a Velociraptor is X-feet
long, but until you see it in the space, you can't appreciate what that means
in terms of your set and the action that needs to take place within it."[3]
The interior of the multi-floor Lockwood Estate was built entirely on sound
stages at Pinewood Studios. The estate set included Eli Mills' office, Dr.
Wu's large underground laboratory, an underground dinosaur containment
facility, separate bedrooms belonging to Benjamin and Maisie Lockwood, and a
large library with dinosaur skeletons and artifacts. When filming was
completed in the Lockwood library, the set was redecorated and converted into
the estate's underground garage, where the dinosaur auction takes place.[3]
Pratt said the film involved significantly more stunts than its
predecessor.[3] An improvised fist fight scene, between Owen and several men
during the dinosaur auction, was added late in filming. It was the first such
scene to be featured in the film series, and was filmed in a single continuous
shot with the use of a [dolly track](/wiki/Tracking_shot "Tracking shot").[76]

On May 10, 2017, it was reported that scenes were being filmed at [Rock
Barracks](/wiki/Rock_Barracks "Rock Barracks") military base, near
[Woodbridge, Suffolk](/wiki/Woodbridge,_Suffolk "Woodbridge, Suffolk").[127]
On May 24, 2017, scenes were shot at Hampshire's [Blackbushe
Airport](/wiki/Blackbushe_Airport "Blackbushe Airport"), which stood in as an
American airfield.[128] Filming in the United Kingdom concluded on June 10,
2017.[108] Up to that point, Trevorrow was present as an on-set writer for
each day of production so he could aid Bayona with any possible script
changes.[129][130] Goldblum shot his scenes in a single day at Pinewood
Studios,[131] during the last day of filming in the United Kingdom.[132] Jones
also filmed his scenes on large sets at Pinewood Studios.[3]

Filming in Hawaii was underway as of June 13, 2017,[133][134] and lasted more
than 25 days, with locations that included [Dillingham
Airfield](/wiki/Dillingham_Airfield "Dillingham Airfield") and Pua'ena
Point.[135] On June 21, 2017, filming began at [Heʻeia Kea Small Boat
Harbor](/wiki/He%CA%BBeia,_Hawaii "Heʻeia, Hawaii"),[136] which served as Isla
Nublar's shipping dock.[3] More than half the harbor was closed for filming,
which required the use of [smoke machines](/wiki/Smoke_machine "Smoke
machine"). Scenes were scheduled to be shot there until the end of the
month.[136][137] Filming also took place in a nearby Heʻeia jungle for scenes
where Owen searches for and locates Blue.[3] As a reference to the first
_Jurassic Park_ film, the scene between Owen and Blue includes an overturned
[Ford Explorer](/wiki/Ford_Explorer "Ford Explorer"), previously featured in
the original film as a Jurassic Park tour vehicle. Trevorrow had initially
considered including the vehicle in a scene in _Jurassic World_ , before
settling on the original Jurassic Park visitor center instead.[138] On June
22, 2017, the film's official title was announced as _Jurassic World: Fallen
Kingdom_.[139] At the time, filming was underway at [Kualoa
Ranch](/wiki/Kualoa_Ranch "Kualoa Ranch") on the Hawaiian island of
[Oahu](/wiki/Oahu "Oahu").[140] Filming at Kualoa Ranch included the exterior
set for a radio tower bunker.[3]

In Hawaii, scenes where characters are running were filmed with the use of the
Edge Arm, a [stabilized camera](/wiki/Camera_stabilizer "Camera stabilizer")
that was attached to a crane, which was mounted to a truck that drove
alongside the actors. This specialized camera allowed for scenes to be shot
steadily despite the truck being driven over rough terrain.[141] The film
includes a scene on Isla Nublar where Claire and Franklin are riding in a
ball-shaped Jurassic World Gyrosphere ride to evade dinosaurs.[142] It was
shot at Kualoa Ranch[3] and in England. Bayona described it as one of the
film's biggest challenges.[142] In Hawaii, the Edge Arm was used to film the
actors riding in the Gyrosphere as it was hauled on a trailer to simulate its
movement.[142][141] In England, an outdoor roller coaster track with a 40-foot
drop was constructed for the Gyrosphere, which Howard and Smith rode in to
shoot a scene where the ride plummets off a cliff and into the water
surrounding Isla Nublar.[142][143] Although this portion of the scene could
have been shot with the use of a [green screen](/wiki/Chroma_key "Chroma
key"), Bayona wanted the actors to express genuine fear for the scene.[143]
The last part of the scene was shot at Pinewood Studios, where a large indoor
tank was constructed and filled with water to depict the submerged ride as
Owen tries to break it open and rescue Claire and Franklin.[142][144] This
portion of the scene was filmed in five different takes that were merged to
make it seem like a single continuous shot.[145] Pratt was aided by a diving
instructor while he shot the scene, which also involved Howard and Smith being
underwater.[142][144] Filming in the tank lasted five days,[3] and required a
crew of 85.[146] It was shot primarily by a [second unit](/wiki/Second_unit
"Second unit") crew, as Bayona was busy directing scenes on other
soundstages.[145]

[David Vickery](/wiki/David_Vickery "David Vickery") and his team at ILM
created the volcanic special effects and consulted
[volcanologists](/wiki/Volcanologist "Volcanologist") for research. According
to Vickery, the team asked "how a volcano of this type might erupt" and also
requested information about "the various stages of lava and [pyroclastic
flow](/wiki/Pyroclastic_flow "Pyroclastic flow"). We are speeding it up a bit
for the sake of our film, but it is definitely all based on real science."[3]
The lava was created through digital effects, although one scene used [cat
litter](/wiki/Cat_litter "Cat litter") set on fire as a stand-in on set, so
the actors would know where to react. The scene was set in an Isla Nublar
bunker as lava begins dripping from the roof. The litter had been soaked in
flammable liquid, and was dropped from 12 different nozzles above the
set.[143][147]

The Main Street section of the Jurassic World theme park was rebuilt on
[Police Beach](/wiki/Papailoa_Beach "Papailoa Beach") in Hawaii for a scene
where Owen and Claire return to the island.[3] The set had been built
previously in Louisiana for filming of the previous _Jurassic World_ , but was
dismantled after filming concluded.[138] For the sequel, Nicholson had part of
the Main Street practically built, although the park's visitor center could
not be constructed in its entirety because of its large size. Unbuilt portions
of the park were created by ILM using digital set extensions. Main Street was
the largest set built in Hawaii, and required more than three months to
complete.[3] Many of the same prop makers returned to recreate the Main Street
set, which then had to be aged to give the appearance of abandonment.[138]

On July 7, 2017, filming took place at Oahu's [Hālona
Blowhole](/wiki/H%C4%81lona_Blowhole "Hālona Blowhole"),[148][149] where
Pratt, Howard and Smith shot scenes on a beach.[3] Filming concluded on July
8, 2017,[150] after shooting was completed at Hālona Blowhole.[151] Bayona
said that making the film was the biggest challenge of his life.[54] The
[original cut](/wiki/Rough_cut "Rough cut") of the film was approximately two
hours and 45 minutes,[152] which the filmmakers considered too long.[153] It
was trimmed to two hours and eight minutes for the final cut.[152] One scene
removed from the film for runtime reasons revealed the character of Zia to be
a lesbian, an idea that came from Bayona and Trevorrow.[153]

### Creatures on screen

See also: [List of cloned animals in the Jurassic Park
series](/wiki/List_of_cloned_animals_in_the_Jurassic_Park_series "List of
cloned animals in the Jurassic Park series")

The film's dinosaurs were created using a combination of animatronics and
[computer-generated imagery](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery "Computer-
generated imagery") (CGI).[3] Special effects artist [Neal
Scanlan](/wiki/Neal_Scanlan "Neal Scanlan") served as the film's creature
effects supervisor,[154] while Vickery and Alex Wuttke were [visual effects
supervisors](/wiki/Visual_effects_supervisor "Visual effects
supervisor").[155] Scanlan worked on the animatronic dinosaurs, while Vickery
and his ILM team created versions of the dinosaurs through CGI.[154] ILM
animators in Vancouver worked on dinosaur stampede scenes, while ILM's London
studio created the remaining creature scenes. Approximately 52 ILM animators
worked on the film.[156] Scanlan worked closely with Bayona and Vickery to
create the creatures.[154] Vickery and ILM did extensive research to
accurately create and depict the dinosaurs, which included consulting with
[paleontologists](/wiki/Paleontologist "Paleontologist"). The ILM team also
referred to elephants and rhinos to determine how the dinosaurs should move
and behave.[3] Dinosaur expert John Hankla, of the [Denver Museum of Nature
and Science](/wiki/Denver_Museum_of_Nature_and_Science "Denver Museum of
Nature and Science"), served as an advisor on the film.[157] After reading fan
thoughts on dinosaurs and speaking with children, Bayona realized that
dinosaur textures and colors were often brought up and said, "I thought that
was the area where I could play with. They feel somehow a little bit more
exotic and richer in this movie."[154] New research had also suggested that
real dinosaurs were more colorful and brighter than previously thought.[3]

The film features more dinosaurs than any previous film in the series.[54]
Bayona wanted to include several new dinosaurs not seen in earlier films,[154]
including _[Allosaurus](/wiki/Allosaurus "Allosaurus")_ ,
_[Baryonyx](/wiki/Baryonyx "Baryonyx")_ , _[Carnotaurus](/wiki/Carnotaurus
"Carnotaurus")_ , _[Sinoceratops](/wiki/Sinoceratops "Sinoceratops")_ ,
_[Stygimoloch](/wiki/Stygimoloch "Stygimoloch")_ , and the fictional
_Indoraptor_.[158] _Baryonyx_ and _Carnotaurus_ were among the creatures
created through CGI.[156] _[Dilophosaurus](/wiki/Dilophosaurus
"Dilophosaurus")_ was in the film's original cut, but was removed.[152] The
film features more animatronic dinosaurs than any previous sequel,[159][160]
and the animatronics used were more technologically advanced than in the
earlier films.[159] Five animatronic dinosaurs were created for the film,
whereas the previous film featured only one.[3] More animatronics were used
because the film features closer interaction between humans and dinosaurs than
its predecessor, including a scene where Howard rides atop the sedated _T.
rex_.[3][161] Bayona said that animatronics "are very helpful on set,
especially for the actors so they have something to perform against. There's
an extra excitement if they can act in front of something real."[154] Scanlan
felt animatronics were not best for every scene: "In some ways it will have an
impact on your shooting schedule; you have to take time to film with an
animatronic. In the balance, we ask ourselves if it is economically and
artistically more valuable to do it that way, or as a post-production effect.
Once we have looked at each particular case, with the director and the VFX
supervisor we decide whether—because of the environment or the
circumstances—it is the right way to go practically."[3]

Scanlan spent more than eight months at Pinewood Studios working on the
creatures before and during filming, with a crew of approximately 35
people.[162] Scanlan's team created functional animatronic models of the _T.
rex_ , the _Indoraptor_ and Blue, while ILM worked on CGI versions of the
creatures.[154][156]

  * The _T. rex_ was one of the first animatronic creatures needed for filming, in the form of a full-scale head and shoulders. ILM sent Scanlan a model of the _T. rex_ from its appearance in _Jurassic World_. Scanlan used it to create a full-scale [3D print](/wiki/3D_printing "3D printing") of the _T. rex_ head and shoulders.[3] The life-sized _T. rex_ animatronic, which had the ability to breathe and move its head, was controlled with joysticks.[159] It was used for a scene where the sedated creature is inside a cage while Owen and Claire attempt to retrieve blood from it. The beginning shots of the scene were created using only the animatronic, while the ending shots solely used CGI. The middle portion of the scene used a combination of the two methods.[156] Within the film's story, the _T. rex_ is portrayed as the same individual featured in previous films.[163] Trevorrow said, "We've been following this same character since the beginning; she's the same _T. rex_ that was in _Jurassic Park_ and in _Jurassic World_. She is iconic—not just because she's a _T. rex_ , but because she's _this T. rex_."[3]
  * The Blue animatronic was created to lay down on an operating table, depicting the animal in an injured state while the character of Zia operates on the creature. Up to 12 [puppeteers](/wiki/Puppeteer "Puppeteer"), hidden under the operating table, were needed to control the animatronic during filming.[3] The scene was shot twice, with and without the Blue animatronic, and the two versions were later combined for a seamless effect.[76] In creating Blue through CGI, the animators referred to the animal's appearance in the previous film.[156] According to Vickery, Blue's movements were designed to resemble a dog: "You look at the way Blue cocks her head and looks up at you. It's exactly like a dog. You're trying to sort of connect the dinosaur with things that you understand as a human."[155]
  * The _Indoraptor_ was primarily created through CGI, while a practical head, neck, shoulders, foot and arm were created for close-up shots.[157] For some scenes, an inflatable _Indoraptor_ stand-in was operated by two puppeteers on set, to be later replaced by a CGI version of the creature.[143] The _Indoraptor_ was designed to have long human-like arms.[76] The creature is depicted as a [quadruped](/wiki/Quadruped "Quadruped") and [biped](/wiki/Biped "Biped"),[156] with a height of approximately 10 ft (3.0 m) tall while standing on two legs.[3] Bayona chose black for the _Indoraptor_ 's color because he wanted the creature to have the appearance of a black shadow, saying "it's very terrifying when you see the Indoraptor in the dark because you can only see the eyes and the teeth."[76]

Scanlan's team also made puppeteering aids, [rod puppets](/wiki/Rod_puppet
"Rod puppet"), and several prop dinosaurs, all created by coordinating with
Vickery to ensure a consistent result between the practical effects and
CGI.[154] Animal motions that could not be perfected with puppetry, such as
blinking, were created with computer technology.[3] Among the puppeteer
dinosaurs were baby velociraptors used for a scene with Pratt.[162] The
scene's final, wider shots used two-wheeled, remote-controlled toys to stand-
in for the baby raptors on set. The toys included a spring which gave them the
ability to jump. The feature was used to get a genuinely startled reaction
from Pratt.[143] Although [motion capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion
capture") was used in the previous film to depict velociraptors, ILM
determined after several tests the technology would not be adequate for
depicting dinosaurs in _Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom_. They chose instead to
use [key frame](/wiki/Key_frame "Key frame") animation done for the previous
films. However, some motion capture was done as a form of
[previsualization](/wiki/Previsualization "Previsualization") to aid
Bayona.[156] ILM used key framing to create scenes involving a large number of
dinosaurs and referred to [high-speed photography](/wiki/High-
speed_photography "High-speed photography") of horses racing for aid in
creating such scenes.[156] The fight scene between Blue and the _Indoraptor_ ,
set in Maisie's bedroom, was designed in London and key framed by ILM. Jance
Rubinchik, animation supervisor for ILM, said the fight was the "trickiest
sequence" because of the lack of previsualization.[156] According to Bayona, a
_[Brachiosaurus](/wiki/Brachiosaurus "Brachiosaurus")_ shown dying in the
volcanic eruption is meant to be the same individual that is first seen in the
original _Jurassic Park_. The _Brachiosaurus_ in the new film was created
using the same animations from the 1993 film. The dinosaur's death was the
last shot on the entire film to be finished; Bayona and the post-production
team worked through the night to perfect the scene's colors and composition,
shortly before the film's release.[76]

For advice on veterinary procedures and animatronic movements, the filmmakers
sought a veterinary surgeon who had experience with [African
wildlife](/wiki/Fauna_of_Africa "Fauna of Africa"). Jonathan Cranston, a
[Gloucestershire](/wiki/Gloucestershire "Gloucestershire") veterinary surgeon,
was recommended for the position because of his experience with wildlife in
[South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa"). He advised Bayona and the
producers on how to choreograph several scenes to accurately depict complex
veterinarian procedures that involved the dinosaurs. Cranston also worked
closely with Pratt, Howard, Pineda and Smith to teach them how to perform such
procedures. He also advised the puppeteers on creating subtle and authentic
animal movements and worked with Bayona on two scenes. Cranston was on set for
12 days, primarily at Pinewood Studios.[164]

## Marketing

A six-second clip from the film was released on November 22, 2017.[165][166]
The first trailer was teased for release on November 30, 2017. This was later
confirmed to be incorrect.[167] Several [teaser trailers](/wiki/Teaser_trailer
"Teaser trailer") and a behind-the-scenes [featurette](/wiki/Featurette
"Featurette") of the film were released in early December
2017,[168][169][170][171] before the release of a full-length trailer on
December 7.[23][168] That month,[172] Universal launched a website for the
Dinosaur Protection Group. It included miscellaneous information about the
group and its effort to save the island's dinosaurs,[14] as well as a video
featuring Howard, Pineda and Smith as their characters.[173] The website was
created by Timothy Glover and Jack Anthony Ewins, who created the [Masrani
Global website](/wiki/Jurassic_World#Marketing_and_promotion "Jurassic World")
for _Jurassic World_.[174] A second trailer aired during [Super Bowl
LII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LII "Super Bowl LII") on February 4, 2018.[175][176] A
30-second teaser trailer was released on April 13, 2018, announcing the
release of a third full trailer on April 18.[177][178] Several of the trailers
and commercials for the film included scenes from the ending that depict the
_Tyrannosaurus rex_ and the _Mosasaurus_ now loose in the world. This
frustrated Trevorrow, who preferred not to show such scenes before the film's
release.[77][179]

Universal had the benefit of a global marketing campaign by its partners
valued at $185 million, more than double the value of the previous film's
partner program.[180] The campaign included nine partners—[Dairy
Queen](/wiki/Dairy_Queen "Dairy Queen"), [Doritos](/wiki/Doritos "Doritos"),
[Dr Pepper](/wiki/Dr_Pepper "Dr Pepper"), [Ferrero SpA](/wiki/Ferrero_SpA
"Ferrero SpA"), [Jeep](/wiki/Jeep "Jeep"), [Juicy Fruit](/wiki/Juicy_Fruit
"Juicy Fruit"), [Kellogg's](/wiki/Kellogg%27s "Kellogg's"),
[M&M's](/wiki/M%26M%27s "M&M's"), and
[Skittles](/wiki/Skittles_\(confectionery\) "Skittles \(confectionery\)")—who
aired television commercials and sold products to promote the film.[180] The
global marketing campaign consisted of 1.3 billion promotional items including
100 million boxes of Kellogg's products and 15 million packages of [Kinder
Joy](/wiki/Kinder_Joy "Kinder Joy") candy by Ferrero.[180] Dairy Queen, a
returning partner from the previous film, sold "Jurassic Chomp" ice cream
desserts in collectable cups, while Doritos and Dr Pepper marketed versions of
their products that featured images of the film's dinosaurs.[180][181] For
Super Bowl LII, Trevorrow directed a Jeep commercial starring Goldblum
featuring a _T. rex_. Within 24 hours of its release, the commercial received
39.7 million online views, more than any film trailer watched online following
its Super Bowl television debut.[180] Universal also teamed up with
[Amazon](/wiki/Amazon_\(company\) "Amazon \(company\)") for a marketing stunt
where a dinosaur-sized box was driven around Los Angeles on a truck to promote
the film.[182][183]

Licensing partners [Mattel](/wiki/Mattel "Mattel"), [Lego](/wiki/Lego "Lego"),
and [Funko](/wiki/Funko "Funko") created toys based on the
film.[184][185][186][187] Mattel produced a variety of toys,[188] including
dinosaurs and action figures,[189][190] as well as [Barbie](/wiki/Barbie
"Barbie") dolls featuring the likeness of Pratt and Howard as their
characters.[185] Mattel released a [mobile app](/wiki/Mobile_app "Mobile app")
titled _Jurassic World Facts_ as a [tie-in](/wiki/Tie-in "Tie-in") to its
dinosaur toys, which included symbols that could be scanned to collect facts
about each creature.[191] Lego released a number of Lego sets and characters
based on the film.[192] A video game, _[Jurassic World
Evolution](/wiki/Jurassic_World_Evolution "Jurassic World Evolution")_ , was
released simultaneously with the film.[193] A two-part [virtual
reality](/wiki/Virtual_reality "Virtual reality") miniseries titled _Jurassic
World: Blue_ , created by Felix & Paul Studios and Industrial Light and Magic,
was released for [Oculus VR headsets](/wiki/Oculus_VR#Products "Oculus VR") as
a film tie-in, featuring Blue on Isla Nublar at the time of the volcanic
eruption.[194][195][196][197] Trevorrow, Glover and Ewins created a website
and campaign for "Extinction Now!" (the antithesis to the Dinosaur Protection
Group), which was launched shortly before the film's release.[174] The
campaign included a [found-footage](/wiki/Found_footage_\(film_technique\)
"Found footage \(film technique\)") clip of a _Tyrannosaurus_ loose in San
Diego, a reference to _[The Lost World: Jurassic
Park](/wiki/The_Lost_World:_Jurassic_Park "The Lost World: Jurassic
Park")_.[174][198]

## Release

_Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom_ had its premiere at the [WiZink
Center](/wiki/WiZink_Center "WiZink Center") in [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid
"Madrid"), Spain, on May 21, 2018.[199][200] The film's international
theatrical release began in Singapore and Malaysia on June 7,[201][202] the
United Kingdom, India, Italy, South Korea and Angola on June 8,[203] and
Pakistan on June 16, 2018. The film was released in the United States on June
22, 2018.[11][84]

### Home media

_Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom_ is scheduled for digital release on September
4, 2018, and [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-ray"), [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD"), [Blu-
ray 3D](/wiki/Blu-ray_3D "Blu-ray 3D") and [4K Blu-ray](/wiki/4K_Blu-ray "4K
Blu-ray") on September 18, 2018.[204]

## Reception

### Box office

As of August 28,
2018[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jurassic_World:_Fallen_Kingdom&action=edit),
_Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom_ has grossed $413.2 million in the United
States and Canada and $881.5 million in other territories for a total
worldwide gross of $1.295 billion. The production budget was in the range of
$170–187 million.[7]

The film crossed the $1 billion mark on July 5, 2018, becoming the 35th film
of all-time to reach this milestone, and the seventh film for Universal. It
also made Universal the second studio (after Disney) to have at least two
films in three different franchises make $1 billion worldwide, alongside _[The
Fast and the Furious](/wiki/The_Fast_and_the_Furious "The Fast and the
Furious")_ and _[Despicable Me](/wiki/Despicable_Me_\(franchise\) "Despicable
Me \(franchise\)")_.[205]

#### United States and Canada

In December 2017, a survey from [Fandango](/wiki/Fandango_\(company\)
"Fandango \(company\)") indicated that _Fallen Kingdom_ was one of the most
anticipated films of 2018.[206] Initial projections three weeks before its
release had the film grossing between $130–150 million in its opening weekend
in the United States and Canada, with [_BoxOffice_
magazine](/wiki/BoxOffice_\(magazine\) "BoxOffice \(magazine\)") estimating a
total of $325–380 million for its final domestic gross.[207][208] By the week
of its release, the low-end projections had reached $135 million.[6] It was
released on June 22, 2018, in 4,475 theaters (the second-widest release ever
behind _[Despicable Me 3](/wiki/Despicable_Me_3 "Despicable Me 3")_) grossing
$58.7 million on its opening day, the second-highest of the franchise and
28th-best on record.[209] The film grossed $15.3 million from Thursday night
previews at 3,600 theaters, down from the $18.5 million grossed by _Jurassic
World_. It ended up debuting at $148 million, the 20th-best opening weekend of
all-time and second highest for Universal. It also marked the second time two
films opened to over $100 million on back-to-back weekends, following
_[Incredibles 2](/wiki/Incredibles_2 "Incredibles 2")_ 's $182.7 million debut
the week before, since May 2007 when _[Shrek the Third](/wiki/Shrek_the_Third
"Shrek the Third")_ and _[Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's
End](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_At_World%27s_End "Pirates of the
Caribbean: At World's End")_ opened to $121.6 million and $114.7 million,
respectively.[209][210][211] In its second weekend the film made $60 million,
a drop of 59% and less than the $105.8 million made by _Jurassic World_ in its
sophomore weekend. In its third weekend made $28.3 million.[212][213]

#### Outside North America

Overseas, the film was released in 48 countries between June 6 and June 8,
2018, including France, Germany, South Korea, the United Kingdom, Italy,
Russia, and Spain. It was projected to gross $130–145 million on its opening
weekend.[214] It made $20.2 million on its first day, including $1.4 million
in France and $1 million in Indonesia. In South Korea, it grossed $9.7 million
([₩](/wiki/South_Korean_won "South Korean won")10.3 billion) and sold over 1
million tickets, setting opening day records for both (beating _[The
Mummy](/wiki/The_Mummy_\(2017_film\) "The Mummy \(2017 film\)")_ 's ₩7.4
billion and _[Avengers: Infinity War](/wiki/Avengers:_Infinity_War "Avengers:
Infinity War")_ 's 980,000).[215] It went on to have an international debut of
$151.1 million, including $8 million from IMAX screenings. Its largest opening
markets were South Korea ($27.2 million), the UK ($19.9 million), France ($10
million), Spain ($9.5 million) and Germany ($9.1 million).[216] In China, the
film was released on June 15 and made $34.4 million ([¥](/wiki/Renminbi
"Renminbi")220 million) on its opening day, nearly double the first day total
of its predecessor ($17.5 million).[217] The film went on to open to $111.9
million (¥715 million), the fourth best-ever in the country for a Hollywood
release (behind _[The Fate of the Furious](/wiki/The_Fate_of_the_Furious "The
Fate of the Furious")_ , _Avengers: Infinity War_ and _[Transformers: The Last
Knight](/wiki/Transformers:_The_Last_Knight "Transformers: The Last
Knight")_), and bringing its two week international total to $372.1 million,
more than the entire lifetime gross of _[Jurassic Park
III](/wiki/Jurassic_Park_III "Jurassic Park III")_ ($368 million).[218] In its
third week of international release the film made $106.7 million, bringing its
total to $561.5 million. China remained one of the top markets with $32.4
million (a standard 71% drop for Hollywood films in the country), while it was
also released in Mexico ($12.3 million), Brazil ($9.2 million) and Australia
$7.9 million).[219] As of July 5, 2018, the film has grossed $245.5 million in
China, making it the 5th highest grossing Hollywood film of all-time in the
country.[205]

### Critical response

On review aggregation website [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten
Tomatoes"), _Fallen Kingdom_ holds an approval rating of 50% based on 331
reviews, and an average rating of 5.6/10. The website's critical consensus
reads, "_Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom_ adds another set piece-packed entry
to the blockbuster franchise, although genuinely thrilling moments are in
increasingly short supply."[220] On [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic
"Metacritic"), which assigns a normalized rating to reviews, the film has a
weighted average score of 51 out of 100, based on 59 critics, indicating
"mixed or average reviews".[221] Audiences polled by
[CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore "CinemaScore") gave the film an average grade
of "A−" on an A+ to F scale, while [PostTrak](/wiki/PostTrak "PostTrak")
reported filmgoers gave it an 82% overall positive score.[209]

_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ 's [Owen
Gleiberman](/wiki/Owen_Gleiberman "Owen Gleiberman") called the film better
than the first _Jurassic World_ but wrote "... [_Fallen Kingdom_] ends up
being just a so-so ride. I hope the next one is an all-out ride—but that for
the first time since Spielberg's 1993 original, it's actually a great one. The
audience for this series has proved that it will turn out in mega-
droves."[222] Lindsey Bahr of the [Associated Press](/wiki/Associated_Press
"Associated Press") wrote, "_Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom_ will not stand up
to rigorous scrutiny, and yet, it’s kind of an enjoyable, preposterous and
thrilling ride that ticks through nostalgia beats like a shopping list."[223]
_[The Boston Globe](/wiki/The_Boston_Globe "The Boston Globe")_ 's Ty Burr
likened the film to a "[Universal Studios](/wiki/Universal_Studios_Hollywood
"Universal Studios Hollywood") theme park ride" noting, "It’s enough for a fun
fright night at the movies but lacks anything else: character, mystery,
wonder, _danger_. The film’s a rush for an audience that only wants the high."
[224]

In a more critical assessment, [Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter
Travers") of _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone_\(magazine\) "Rolling Stone
\(magazine\)")_ said "...this sequel has the perfunctory vibe that comes from
filmmakers who cynically believe the public will buy anything _T. rex_
-related, no matter how shoddy the goods or warmed-over the plot." [225]
Senior Editor Matt Goldberg of [Collider](/wiki/Collider_\(website\) "Collider
\(website\)") also criticized the screenplay stating, "The film is too lazy to
even bother with the modest housekeeping of explaining its characters’
motives."[226] _[The Verge](/wiki/The_Verge "The Verge")_ 's Bryan Bishop was
equally critical, writing, "Like its predecessor, _Fallen Kingdom_ is
overstuffed with ethical conundrums, and not sophisticated enough to fully
engage with them ... the movie's villains become such cartoony caricatures
that it's impossible to take _Fallen Kingdom_ 's attempted philosophical
musings seriously."[227] Sam Machkovech of _[Ars Technica](/wiki/Ars_Technica
"Ars Technica")_ called the film a [B movie](/wiki/B_movie "B movie")
consisting of "a sixth-grade sketchbook mash of dino-murder, cartoonish
villains, and plot holes",[228] while Travis M. Andrews of _[The Washington
Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")_ said the film had
"achieved the impossible: it makes dinosaurs boring."[229]

In a positive review, Scott Mendelson of _[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_
wrote, "_Fallen Kingdom_ is a gorgeous, mostly enjoyable blockbuster that
looked great in IMAX. That it doesn't cash all the checks it tries to write is
why it's merely a good movie instead of a great one."[230] Writing for _[The
Hollywood Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ ,
John DeFore also praised the film saying, "Finally making good on its name,
J.A. Bayona's _Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom_ says goodbye to the park for
good, not just carrying the de-extincted dinos off the island but freeing
itself from the genre trappings of the previous four films."[231]
_[Exclaim!](/wiki/Exclaim! "Exclaim!")_ 's Alex Hudson said the film is "a
straight-ahead monster movie: it's dumb, occasionally gory, and mostly plenty
of fun ... It won't rekindle your childhood fascination with dinosaurs, but it
makes for a suitably silly creature feature."[232]

Many reviewers singled out the scene where a lone
_[Brachiosaurus](/wiki/Brachiosaurus "Brachiosaurus")_ , stranded on Isla
Nublar, succumbs to the volcanic fumes while the characters helplessly watch
from the departing ship, as "poignant" or "haunting", especially given the
species' role in the first movie.[222][225][233][234]

## Sequel

Further information: [Jurassic Park § Jurassic World 3
(2021)](/wiki/Jurassic_Park#Jurassic_World_3_\(2021\) "Jurassic Park")

An untitled sequel, known as _Jurassic World 3_ , is scheduled for release on
June 11, 2021.[235][236] Trevorrow will direct the film,[237] and write the
screenplay with [Emily Carmichael](/wiki/Emily_Carmichael_\(filmmaker\) "Emily
Carmichael \(filmmaker\)"). It is based on a story by Trevorrow and Connolly.
Trevorrow will also serve as executive producer with Steven Spielberg;
Marshall and Crowley will serve as producers.[238][239][235] Pratt and Howard
will reprise their roles for the film.[240]
